This used to be my favorite Japanese restaurant when I was in my early 20's. Back then, I couldn't tell the difference between good and bad Japanese food. And back then, I didn't have a Japanese boyfriend who turned me into a sushi snob. 

This place has mediocre Japanese food (IMO). I actually prefer their cooked foods more than their sushi. Their sushi is not that great. I guess I'm not into those big ass godzilla rolls that everyone else likes. You know, those rolls that are deep fried and drenched in sauce.  I would rather go to Minami, or Rumble Fish for sushi. Well, like everyone says "You get what you pay for."  

I ordered their saba shioyaki/chicken kaarage combo ($7.99). It was alright. I'm curious to try their curry udon special. I wonder if its any good. I also have to mention service here wasn't that great. 

More like 2.5 stars. But I'll give them 3 cause of their reasonable prices.
author: B B.

description:
Kitaro is just like Kiki's on 9th & Irving. They have coupons on the back of safeway receipts and the menus are basically the same. Kitaro isn't as bright as Kiki's, which is something I like. They have some relatively creative rolls, but nothing special. The fish usually tastes fresh.

Whenever I come here, nothing really seems legitimately Japanese. This is coming from a girl whose favorite Japanese restaurant is run by Chinese folk though. :P

The service here is pretty good, I remember my friends went out to smoke & I sat there by myself. Then his phone rang so I walked out and gave it to him, they didn't even say anything that ALL of us left the table. Well obviously we were going back in to pay, but I would feel skeptical if an entire table of people just bounced. Also the waitresses are very nice.

Oh yeah, this place is really cheap! I guess that's a plus. :)
author: Erica A.

description:
In many ways I assert my authority over foods that I know a decent amount about. If a restaurant claims to be "authentic (insert cuisine type) cuisine," then sure, I'll be pretty harsh when I critique it, or if it claims to make the best red velvet cake, then I will hold it to that standard. 

What I do not do, and what really grates on my nerves about a lot of the reviews written here, is assume that every Japanese or whatever type of ethnic restaurant will claim to be authentic. Kitaro does not in any way claim to be "authentic Japanese cuisine," people. 

Kitaro is being held to a standard that it never claimed to live up to. It is NOT a restaurant that should be compared with authentic udon or katsu shops like those in Japan, nor should it be compared to mom and pop Japanese sushi places in the U.S. that are so stringent about the quality of raw fish that they will have fresh fish shipped daily from Japan. Kitaro is run by a bunch of Chinese people who recognized what patrons wanted -- cheap, affordable sushi and Americanized sushi rolls as well as combination plates. If you don't want to enjoy the godzilla roll or the Mexican roll or any of the other specialty rolls that they offer here, then don't come here and complain about the food not being authentic, because they never claimed to be authentic! 

I don't understand how anyone could think that this place is not good for the money that they are paying to eat here for, nor do I understand how anyone would be ashamed to get a party platter or a specialty roll here. Keeping in mind that authenticity is not Kitaro's goal, I think that they make pretty damn good food, and it is obviously good and popular, otherwise why is the restaurant is always jam packed with a wait at almost all hours of the day? The amount of business that Kitaro gets speaks for itself. 

 And in a time and day when there's a recession going on, and a lot of people can't afford $50-200/head for "authentic" sushi, haters are NOT appreciated. If you want to be snooty and assert that you know about what sushi or katsu really is, then go somewhere else and eat and be self-important.
author: Yvonne W.

description:
This place is about bang for the buck not quality, and for that reason it is 4 stars. Not only is almost everything on the menu very cheap, they give you a big portion and you can often get coupons for 15% off your entire bill, making it even cheaper. It can get a little busy, but usually it's manageable.

Qualitywise, I think Kitaro still stands pretty well to any Sushi place in the $$ range. In particular, the Salmon Sashimi is fantastic, it is the best Salmon Sashimi I have ever had even though I have been to places that charge nearly 3x as much. I like it so much I usually get two entree's worth when I go. I could literally eat this salmon sashimi everyday of my life and not get bored. 

Bottom line: This is very good Japanese food at a cheap price. I think the rolls are generally not that great compared to other places, but the entree's are very good and the salmon sashimi is excellent.
author: Alex S.

description:
One word says it all "CHEAP SUSHI"

You pay for what you get, especially the next day. 

I've gone to Kitaro's many years ago and they were decent. On a budget, I stopped by and grabbed a quick bite. Boy did I feel it this morning. I guess the fish was not as fresh as it looked.
author: Scott L.

description:
If you're in the mood for a cheap, good place for Japanese food, Kitaro is a place you should consider. The sushi rolls range from $3.50 to about $5.00. The quality isn't the best I've had, but the price is really hard to beat. I love that they're open relatively late. 

I had the spicy tuna roll and California. Both were OK, but really nothing beyond that. The spicy tuna was just tuna and siracha, so the quality really wasn't that great.

Overall, I like Kitaro and will definitely visit it again if I'm in the mood for cheap sushi.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Stopped in here pretty randomly today and had a very tasty meal. Lots of food for what I would call reasonable prices (but I don't live in the city). 

The pieces were all there; large table of young students, one old woman who was clearly a regular, generically asian masks on the wall, and a sign that clearly could (but did not) light up that said "Godzilla Roll."

I enjoyed the miso, the negihama roll, and the dynamite roll. The gf enjoyed her box of assorted food but thought the chicken rubbery.

Worth stopping in. As others have commented service is also very fast.
author: Ian D.

description: Super affordable sushi. Ridiculously cheap prices. Really low priced Japanese food. And a menu with affordably cheap low priced sushi. Fun vibe. So SF.
author: Champ M.

description:
I've gone here for the past six years.  I went here yesterday for lunch with a friend to grab a quick bite to eat.  This place has been our really cheap quick sushi fix and not much has change since the first time I've gone--at least from what I remember.  

He got the tempura meal with the godzila roll.  I got the beef teriyaki roll and the dynamite roll (i think).  The dynamite and godzilla roll were pretty tasty but nothing that would get me to come back there just to have.

I'm a fan of this place because it's cheap and to me it's a reliably quick fix for sushi.
author: Allan G.

description:
Kitaro definitely satisfied my Japanese craving. They have a wide selection of Japanese dishes and sushi. I had the gyoza, veggie udon, and inari. Everything was delicious - the udon noodles were nice and chewy. The food came out fast, the tea was yummy, and the wasabi hit the spot.

Oh and it's cheeeeaaap... My boyfriend and I ate for about $20!
author: Christy D.

description: I used to come here all the time when I was in high school (4years ago). This place was close to my home and high school so my friends and I would come often. It's a cheap place for broke students but I don't think I ever really go here any more now that I'm older. There are better places I'd prefer for sushi. Service is okay. The food is okay. The best thing about this place is the price.
author: Connie Y.

description:
Kitaro has been my go-to sushi place in SF for about 7 years now. They have a pretty large selection of rolls, and the combination of prices and quality can't be beat!

My favorite roll to order is the Godzilla roll (tempura'd spicy tuna roll with a tasty wasabi sauce on it). I also like to order the Pink Dragon roll (cooked salmon on California roll), Tiger roll, Kamikaze roll, and one or two others. The only drawback is that they use imitation crab (not sure if this was always the case), though I don't usually mind since I don't order many rolls that have crab in them.

You can usually get out of Kitaro for less than $40 for two people (tax and tip included). The one drawback about this place is the location; it's pretty difficult to find parking (you might circle around for a good half hour). That said, I'm always happy after eating at Kitaro.
author: John C.

description:
You get what you pay for.

The food here is very cheap, quality and price. I ordered 3 different rolls.  The soft shell crab tasted like it has been sitting out since the day before.  The salmon on the pink dragon roll tasted like it was microwaved.  The unagi on the tiger roll left a bone stuck in the roof of my mouth for the whole night.

The restaurant is set up like the elementary lunch room where you can hear everybody's conversation.
author: Danny P.

description:
This is one of many of our neighborhood sushi places. And considering I'm a vegetarian and my husband doesn't like fish, we don't eat Japanese food that often. But I do love me a good veggie roll and my husband can always eat chicken teriyaki.This was our second visit to Kitaro, after a day of walking around our 'hood. Our first visit was not so memorable (maybe b/c we were on a double date w/dull people) but this visit was surprisingly delicious! I had the seaweed salad and the Irish Roll (asparagus, green beans & avocado) and my husband had the chicken teriyaki lunch combo (which came w/veggie tempura, salad, rice, miso soup). Everything tasted delicious. The rice was soft and the meal was just fantastic! We're not sushi connoisseurs, so we can't vouch for the seafood, but we enjoyed our meal & experience very much. And after 2 large Sapporos, we left happily with a $30 bill! So cheap!!!
***Yes, you should try this place!***
author: Ms. B.

description: Have been a big fan of Kitaro since the '90's. Back when I wasn't a vegetarian I remember their spider rolls, side salad dressing, and oyster katsu fondly. As a vegetarian now there are still many options- here are a few: irish roll, garden veggie sushi party tray, vegetable tempura, vegetable udon, vegetable donburi, seaweed salad, shiitake roll, fried sweet potato roll, etc. Great prices for fresh sushi. Can't go wrong. Have a great time!
author: Lilly J.

description:
Very Very Cheap Prices for sushi! 
Lunch and Dinner Combo is very good! 
it can be very busy from 7 till closing time. 
not 5 stars because it could be a little cleaner and more time taken to 
prepare the rolls ( not too aesthetically pleasing ) taste good tho!
author: Jake R.

description: Cheap.  Ingredients aren't fresh.  Rolls fall apart (rice is dry / rolls have been sitting around too long).  I really can't think of any redeeming qualities.
author: Heidi M.

description:
I got 2 rainbow rolls to go the other day and when I got them home ---

No unagi! 

On either of them!

Sheesh.
author: Sharon J.

description:
3.5 really.
Yes, the food is mediocre at best. No, you're not going to find anything out of the ordinary or special on this restaurant's menu. But what gives Kitaro an edge over the dozens and dozens of other small Japanese places in the city are its ridiculously low prices. For example, I had a bento-box special featuring fried shrimp and chicken katsu with a salmon and avocado roll on the side all for $13. So the main reason for coming here isn't to have excellent-tasting Japanese cuisine, but rather a filling, okay-tasting meal that's the exact same quality at most other places, but roughly 30% cheaper. I've only seen a small number of places that can match this formidable food quality:price ratio. Not to mention the service is good, the place is clean and the food comes out quick.
author: Raymond P.

description: I never been here till my friend brought me and let me say it will be my first and last visit here.  The food here lacks taste! The prices are cheap but it won't fulfill my requirements on decent japanese food.  The food was awful, chicken udon was not up to my standards because the soup base lacked taste and favoring.  The only okay dish was the firecracker roll but even that wasn't good enough for me.
author: Ann L.

description:
if you love sushi but are on a budget this is the place for you.  Although the quality is not the best (its still pretty good), you'll get alot of food for your money (especially the sashimi).

Parking around this spot though is very challenging!
author: james s.

description:
Kitaro is another Japanese restaurant with cheap, affordable prices serving adequately quality food at nearly ridiculous portions. This would be one of my choices for Japanese if I just want to satisfy my basic need for tempura or rolls, but there are better options out there. 

What to recommend? Any rolls and the Bento boxes are quite the striking value. Do expect portions of each to be generous. Often times, a Bento is more than enough to fill me up. I haven't tried anything else outside of Bentos and rolls, but I'm confident that it lives up to the standard. 

Another good thing about Kitaro is how it'll comfortably sit large parties. Pretty flexible for those reunions or what not.

Overall, this popular Japanese restaurant will fill your stomachs without emptying your wallets. It's inviting at times and the ambiance is comfortable. Parking is limited to metered or residential and it could get difficult on the busy hours.
author: Jeremy L.

description: I must say that I am very impressed with the quality of the food and pricing.  If you exclude the parking issue, which includes public garage parking, this place would receive 5 stars in my opinion.  I especially like the sushi and udon selection.  We love the convenience of being able to drop by on our way home from the city or peninsula, back north before the GGB.  Anyway, the waitresses do not hassle you about how one is faring on the food.  Also, with children, they are willing to bring small plates for sharing the meal.
author: Peter C.

description:
Let me caveat this review - if you're looking for great ambiance, awesome presentation and/or innovation in sushi making - this is not the place for you.

However, if you're looking for a good, cheap sushi fix that doesn't serve skeptically "fresh" fish, than this is your place.

I love kitaro. It's where I know I can get fresh salmon and hamachi sashimi at bargain basement prices. I am not a fan of the long lines due to lack of reservation taking - so I normally don't come during peak dining hours. I usually go on a Sunday around 5pm after a round of golf. It hits the spot everytime.

If you like the rolls, the godzilla roll is probably their pride and joy.
author: Theresa N.

description:
What happened to the quality of this place?

Ok we're in a recession and all, but when customers pay good money they expect good food in exchange.  

For realz yelp, i've experienced WAYYYYYYYYY better sushi.
author: Elliot Y.

description:
I love how this place is very cheap and has decent sushi. Their Dynamite Roll was the bomb! It was cooked perfectly. I also got their lunch bento box with Chicken Teriyaki and California Roll. It was alright, had better but it was decent enough for me to finish. 

The service was great and waiters were very friendly. I will come back again when I'm in the area.
author: Christine E.

description:
Get the Chicken Teriyaki, it is good.  I love the salad here and they don't cheap you out on the portions for the chicken.  And did I mention it is only $6 at lunch.  Where can you eat food like that for that price.  Very great place to chill and enjoy some good Teriyaki. 

Highly recommended for Casual eating.
author: Sam O.

description:
This is your typical Japanese restaurant. Mediocre. The sauce tastes like it came from a bottle you can purchase at a supermarket.

It just seemed like not much effort was put into all of the dishes. I usually order chicken teriyaki... It was okay, that's all. Edible, thank god. But just okay.
author: Stephanie J.

description: The prices were decent, but their food is only mediocre. I mean, if you love your rolls to be lathered up in batter then deep fried and smothered with cream sauce, then this place is for you. But I personally prefer something a little more light and clean when it comes to my sushi rolls. The wait here is sometimes lengthy, and I hate how they don't have a sizable waiting area (I'm not one who enjoys having to wait outside in the chilly SF weather). Pro about this place: semi-fast service once you actually get seated. Good for a quick bite.
author: Patricia N.

description:
LOVE KITAROS!

The cheap and easy choice menu makes this place our #1 sushi place to go to even though we now live in Marin.  

Parking is always crazy in SF so I'd suggest going to Kitaros before 7pm or after 830pm on the weekends.  During the week days it's not too bad.

We always go for the Chicken Karage (yes, I know it's like fried chicken, but it's so good) and the Dynamite Roll.  

For my boyfriend and I we almost never spend over $30.00 when we choose a main entree and 3-4 rolls.  With 4 or 5 people the bill is never over $60.00 even with drinks.
author: Crystal R.

description:
this place was absolutely disgusting. the sushi rolls we ordered were warm, and the fish was old and looked/tasted like it was rotten. I was a waitress myself, and as a result I hardly ever send food back to a kitchen, even if they mess up my order a bit. On this occasion, I was so sickened by this warm, semi-rotten yellow-tail in my roll, that I called my waitress over and talked to her. I tried my best to be really friendly about it, stressing that it was not her fault, and I just wanted it taken off the bill. But when I showed her how bad it looked and smelled, she argued with me, got defensive, and insisted that is how it always looked, how it should look.

needless to say we will NEVER eat here again. The sushi comes out really fast when you order it, but the quality is extremely poor and the service unfriendly. I would give this place zero stars if I could.
author: Sam S.

description:
I wrote this and then realized Kitaro already had 450+ reviews. But I'll throw in my two-cents anyway. This is the best quality Japanese food for the price that I've seen anywhere.

I ordered the unadon (unagi donburi). It was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Perfect (but then again, it's pretty hard to ruin unagi). 

I also sampled the hamachi and the dynamite roll. Although I didn't care much for the spicy sauce on the dynamite roll (I'm a wimp when it comes to spicy foods and it didn't have much flavor), I can say that the yellowtail and the tuna were fresh (no smell, good coloring, super soft). I'll admit, I was surprised by the quality given how cheap the restaurant is. 

The service was okay. There were four of us at our table and we were given our food in waves. So while one person was served, it took probably another four minutes before another person's food came out. I want to believe that this is indicative that they prepared the rolls as ordered. We were also seated at a table placed awkwardly behind the hostess stand, so we were sort of trapped in our seats if they were helping someone at the front.

So yeah, it's just basic Americanized Japanese food, but you'll be hard pressed to find fish as fresh as theirs for this cheap anywhere else.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I like Kitaro. Except their take-out trays like kind of suck.  I dont know why it is but when you eat there, the sushi comes out fresher and prettier. 

Duh its not the best sushi ever, but hello its cheap and we could all stand to have a lil extra in our wallets these days. 

Can get totally crowded, parking is hard to come by, but worth it! My bf and I can fill up here for under 20 dollas holla!
author: Amy S.

description:
It is what it is... a place to get average, affordable sushi. It's not the type of place i'd suggest someone bring a hot and classy date to, or anyone with some sort of elevated standard, but for a simple and satisfying meal that's fresh, I have placed Kitaro at the top of my list, becoming my go-to fast food.

The rolls, I have to admit, are less than groundbreaking. Frankly, they're quite boring. However, what I am absolutely a fan of... ready for it? Is THE SASHIMI !!!

Sashimi dinners come complete with 12 nicely cut slices of Hamachi (or your fish of choice,) salad, and a bowl of rice. I have been coming here and ordering this almost weekly for the past year and a half. My parents, from who I've inherited my love for sashimi, agree that although it's not the freshest one can get, it's pretty close considering the establishment. 

I always ask what the freshest fish is that day, and that helps me narrow my choices. And it usually guarantees that I will really enjoy my food.

* I actually wrote this review simply to bump it up a star after all the less than mediocre places I've been to recently.
author: Deanna T.

description:
This place is great for cheap, fresh sushi.

I've only ever gotten take-out, but the prices are cheap and the fish is fresh. There are many rolls to choose from - everything from makimono to fancy junk - and nigiri options for days! A great sushi place in the Richmond...can't go wrong here!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
The best inexpensive sushi in the Richmond District for sure.  We get coupons in the mail for Kitaro; where else can you get a 60 piece platter of decent sushi for $20?  Perfect for having friends over, or for eating a ton of sushi by yourself!

We usually order off the Makimono menu.  The California, Negihama, and Chicken Teriyaki never disappoint.  The shrimp tempura special roll is excellent as well.

We've never actually eaten at the restaurant; we usually pick up and take home with us.  It's unfortunate that they do not deliver, as parking can be quite tricky when picking up your order.
author: Tim N.

description:
According to all the iffy Kitaro reviews, this place is mediocre at best, which I find odd, 'cause every time I go here it's friggin' packed!

Where else can I get an order of edamame, 2 *life-nourishing* miso soups, 4 different maki rolls and a large Sapporo for like, $25 bucks total?  

That's an average of $3.13 per item, and it's good enough for me. :D
author: Karen F.

description:
Conveniently, my friend & I were in need of a sushi fix one afternoon & he told me about this place, so I decided to check it out. It was like 4, & usually, all the sushi places I know of would be closed, but this place definitely wasn't! So thank you for being open unlike Little Tokyo next door.

My initial reaction when I opened the menu was how bizarrely inexpensive everything was! I thought it was hella surreal, but how can I pass up a price like that? I got a Tiger Roll & Unagi Nigiri, for about $12 total. That's the price I would normally pay for a Caterpillar or Dragon elsewhere, without the Unagi Nigiri! So, that was definitely a save.

It didn't feel like we even waited for our food; it was out with the quickness. The rolls packed taste, & were able to fit in my mouth without me making a mess (trust me, I'm the sloppiest eater, ever). & Even the ginger tasted better than a few other places I could think of. Wasn't an upset, but could've been a bit more pieces in the roll.

Definitely felt like I've won here.
author: Mike M.

description: It's pretty cheap here, and their service and food is hit or miss. The rolls are decent, but you get what you pay for. A fave for me when I'm on a budget and need a sushi fix.
author: Mary S.

description:
I don't think the 3 star average rating is justified so I thought I should write about one of my favorite sushi places.  In short, Kitaro is cheap and good.  The nigiri is very good and I love their rolls.  I think the portions are above average and you can eat here for two for under $30 easy, with alcohol.  How can you beat that?  Oh, and you almost never have to wait for a table.  
Now, it's not crazy good like Blowfish or something, but for these prices it blows most out of the water.  It's a bit of a drive in the Outer Richmond, but well worth it if you're in Golden Gate Park or at the beach.  Kitaro proves that quality sushi doesn't have to cost a fortune.  Oh, and my friend Jaime says the Japanese-style fried chicken is the bomb.
author: Eric F.

description:
Decision night on a date night. Three Japanese restaurants located next to each other...Kitaro, Little Tokyo and Sakana Bune in front of us and we didn't know which one to go to. We went to the restaurant staring right in front of us...

A very typical sushi joint, Kitaro is probably not the first thing to come to mind when in the mood for japanese...almost next to having to buy packaged sushi at Trader Joe's. After eating at several sushi joints, Kitaro doesn't have the creativity and originality in its sushi dishes. I didn't find much excitement in their menu selection and there wasn't anything in the menu that caught my eye or made my mouth water. Also, noticed that a lot of the rolls fell apart when I picked it up by my chopsticks plus the rice they used seemed dry...not sticky & fermented like it's supposed to. It was a rushed job by the chef if you asked me. I was hungry and dared thought of asking for a spoon to help me out with my sushi but I know better not to. Wouldn't want to recreate the first timer experience of eating miso soup with a spoon again
author: Charmian D.

description: I don't know why people come here more than Kiki. Every time I come here at night, it is crowded with people. Their pieces are actually smaller than Kiki and actually doesn't taste as good. Also, this place is much smaller as well, which may be the reason why it seems crowded all the time. However, I do like their Godzilla Roll and their Dynamite.
author: Ariel J.

description: Food is decent and so are the prices. It's okay if you're craving japanese food in the area. I've had better though..
author: Mertani G.

description:
Ugh...I can't believe this, but I'm taking a star away from my previous review. Although Kitaro is a staple in my family (I think my mom goes multiple times a week for this salmon teriyaki)...I've realized that: THE SUSHI ISN'T THAT GREAT.

I realized this last weekend. Dad and I decided to order a couple of rolls, instead of the usual combo dinners (try the beef teriyaki or the tempura udon). 

And...the sushi was just...so-so. I realized just how "so-so" it was, when I went to eat two doors down at Sakana Bune yesterday, and realized, DAMN...Sakana Bune's sushi is hellllla better.
author: Misha F.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place for a cheap date with my sweetie.  The ambiance is cute, nothing fancy.  The food comes out pretty quick.  But the sushi itself is pretty fresh and really tasty.  Rainbow roll is $6.50 instead of the normal $10-$12 elsewhere.  We usually end up leaving for under $45 stuffed, sometimes less than $30.  I love all the different rolls, and they have a $7 special for six nigiri and a CA roll.  Their sister restaurant Kiki on 9th and Irving is exactly the same, but less of a date place and more of a casual spot.  

Daisuki Kitaro....oishii desune!
author: Ashley S.

description: I was taken here by a group of friends that had made the place out to be an great sushi joint. I walk in and see a full house and think it's gotta be good if it's this busy. I was fooled. The sushi was not great by all means, and wasn't extremely awful. However some bites, I could taste the not so fresh fish. The seaweed salad was so saucy and drenched in dressing I couldn't even taste the seaweed. It was awful. It was not worth it, and I would never come back here again. Why waste your time on sushi that is just OK.... when you have so many better options to choose from in the city!
author: Natasha S.

description:
Considering the price and the portion, a Ok....
Maybe you can skip sashimi on this one. 
Recommend rolls and those combos, big portion.
I really wasn't expecting much, my co worker was just telling me how big the portions were and how inexpensive it was. It's true.
author: RB B.

description: this place is okay. Like any chinese japanese restaurant. NOthing fancy. The food is alright. IT does keep you full
author: Hei Ming C.

description: Kitaro is not anything to lose your mind over, but it IS a place where you can initiate the hesitant into the sushi world without breaking the bank.  The basics are all here from CA Roll to Unagi, but the tepid will most likely jump at the Kitaro Roll (Chicken of the sea?).  Every journey begins with a single step, and for the sushi amateur Kitaro is an approachable first step on the path to refinement.
author: Michael D.

description:
Quick, Moderate, and Satisfying Sushi can be purchased here.

Whenever I go for a cheap sushi night I go to kitaro because Safeway use to offer those %15 off bill coupons on Safeway's receipts. 

I truthfully like their tempura; perfectly battered.

Although I feel they could invest in some better looking cups, I feel the glasses are overused and became blurry. 

Altogether is a cheap eat and decent food. Not bad!
author: Tony C.

description:
The dynamite sushi roll was dynamite. 
Usually sushi this cheap isn't this good. 
Very fast and friendly service.
author: emmy a.

description:
My friend once suggested we eat at Kitaro and I quickly punched him in the throat and set his car on  fire.  There's a reason the sushi there is so "affordable."  Good fish is not cheap.  This isn't a very difficult concept to grasp.  No restaurant can stay open long if they lose money on each piece of sushi they sell.   

I understand if you like to eat there because it's inexpensive, just don't tell me that the fish is good.  There's a reason the "sushi" mentioned here are mostly rolls that mask the taste of the fish with cream cheese or hot sauce.

If you want some reasonable sushi made by chinese folk, you might want to try walking a couple blocks to Blue Fin on Clement.  It's not the best in the city, but at least the fish doesn't taste a few days old.
author: Umetaro J.

description: Yum! Cheap and good! Need I say more..
author: SF S.

description:
Service was slow and bad.
Old fish, Rice was wet.
Roll was falling apart.
Wasted my time and money.
So, here we go again.
Famous jiveass-roll song.

They tried to make me go to Kitaro but I said, 'No, no, no.'
Yes, I've been black but when I come back you'll know, know, know
I ain't got the time and if my friends think I'm fine
they're tried to make me go to Kitaro but I won't go, go, go

I'd rather be at home with mary
I ain't got seventeen dollars
'Cause there's nothing
There's nothing I can eat there
That I can't order from Mr. Kitaro

I didn't get a lot in class
But I know it don't come in a shot glass

They tried to make me go to Kitaro but I said, 'No, no, no.'
Yes, I've been black but when I come back you'll know, know, know
I ain't got the time and if my daddy thinks I'm fine
He's tried to make me go to Kitaro but I won't go, go, go

The man said, 'Why do you think you're here?'
I said, 'I got no idea
I'm gonna, I'm gonna lose my appetite
So I always keep a Sake-bottle near.'
He said, 'I just think you're depressed,
Kiss me, yeah baby, and get a 49'ers roll.'

They tried to make me go to Kitaro but I said, 'No, no, no.'
Yes, I've been black but when I come back you'll know, know, know

I don't ever wanna jiveass-roll again
I just, ooh, I just need a Nigiri
I'm not gonna spend even ten dollars
Have everyone think I'm on the mend

It's not just my pride
It's just 'til these tears have dried

They tried to make me go to Kitaro but I said, 'No, no, no.'
Yes, I've been black but when I come back you'll know, know, know
I ain't got the time and if my daddy thinks I'm fine
He's tried to make me go to Kitaro but I won't go, go, go
author: Nobu K.

description:
It's always nice to have a backup restaurant available.

Kitaro fits the bill for a decent backup choice for some sushi. Today it played third string behind Shimo and Oyaji. Since, the first 2 choices were closed for lunch, Kitaro became a player.

My friend and I each ordered a sashimi combo, a 12 slice mix of tuna, salmon, albacore, yellowtail and octopus, served with salad, miso soup and rico. For $8.99, I'd say its a pretty good deal.

The combo came out scary fast, like right after we were served our miso soup. I guess it's not too hard to slice up sashimi. Nonetheless, I was a little apprehensive about the sashimi at first. But, I was surprised at how good the pieces were. Everything was fresh and tasty, except for the yellowtail, which lacked the usual soft, fatty texture.

For dessert, I tried their frozen yogurt of the day... mango. Yea... really... frozen yogurt here? But, I had some time to kill because we were waiting up for one more person to join us for lunch. And it was scary how our waiter did not know what the flavor of the day was.

But... the fro-yo was actually pretty good.... a little more creamier than the norm though.

All in all a pretty good lunch. Thank you to the backups.
author: Sam T.

description:
Decent vegetarian sushi options. The sweet potato roll was an interesting mix of warm sweet potato and the cooler rice/seaweed, with a tart dark sauce.  I also liked the fat vegetarian futo maki roll, with egg and a variety of other goodies.

My fish-eating dining companions raved about the dynamite roll (crackly from fried tempura, and red hot from spicy tuna).

The price is right, too, with many rolls in the $2 range.
author: angela n.

description:
Here's what I've been known to order at Kitaro:

Dynamite Roll
Tempura Roll
49ers Roll 
Kamikaze Roll
Mexican Roll 
Kitaro Roll 
Rock n' Roll 
Hawaii Roll 
Philadelphia Roll 
Alaska Roll
Spider Roll 
Rainbow Roll 
San Francisco Roll  
Irish Roll
Pink Dragon Roll  
Tiger Roll

Duh, not all by myself!!!  There are usually at least 5 to 10 other people there.  

In the booths surrounding me...

Don't look at me like that.  I'M FREAKING STARVING.
author: Rachel G.

description: OK sushi nothing special........... staff is nice..... sushi rolls a little over price there is a lot other sushi bars with better rolls then here .... most likely would not go there again......
author: Boris M.

description:
Everyone knows where this spot it.  My favorite table are the corners next to the window because when it gets packed, you're next to another table about 1 foot away.  It's hard to not listen to their weird convos.

I like it here a lot.  I would go here a bunch of times and the food is delish todos los dias.  I tried the karaagi and its nasty, girl.  Its deep fried sushi with some weird crab cakey crap. But overall the food is good.  I always get the chicken teryizzle because its a special everyday by 5pm - for only 4.99 ...or 5?  

I don't like it how they charge hot tea.  Sakanabune does not do this type of hustling.  I need them coins for munizzle.  It's all good.
author: Jonathan P.

description: I have been to this restaurant more than ten times already. The food and the prices are both very decent. In addition, I've always gotten large portions of food for my bento box. For example, I usually have twelve pieces of salmon sashimi instead of seven, which is what is listed on the menu. Definitely try the tempura roll! The shrimp tempuras are still fresh and crispy even when they're wrapped into a roll. The batter is neither too thick or oily. The best part is that this restaurant always sends 15% coupons and sushi coupons to their customers. Also, they always have coupons printed on the back of Safeway receipts so NEVER THROW YOUR SAFEWAY RECEIPTS AWAY!!!
author: Nicole T.

description:
I went here for lunch with my friend and I found it to be decent although I know that when getting rolls things may not be as fresh

Whatever maybe it was the fact that we had 2 large Sake's and 2 large beers plus ordered several rolls and it was only $40.00.

I will be back here again
author: Kim R.

description:
When I want cheap Japanese food, I'll go to Kitaro.  When I want moderately decent Japanese food, I'll avoid Kitaro.

Their lunch specials are actually pretty good, but it lacks the flavor of other Japanese restaurants, especially since there are many of them in the vicinity.  I can't really complain about the price or the service, but it's not on my go-to Japanese restaurants.

Another reviewer mentioned Kitaro as being a great colon cleanser;  my friends and I couldn't agree more.
author: Tori S.

description:
The best way to describe Kitaro's..McDonald's meets Sushi? McSushi? That's right. 

I must admit I order a sushi tray from Kitaro's at least once a week. It's perfect for me and it will be perfect for you if you can do the following 3 things: 

1. Born with a tough stomach: yes the food here isn't the freshest or greatest. It's never made me super sick so it's fine with me where I've heard some people do worst. 
2. Eat at home: The seating can get packed at night but the service is sub par. I pick up the food and eat it at the comforts of my own home. 
3. Not a sushi elitist. That's right..it's average at best. 

But so why the 4 stars. Because it's so damn cheap!!!!! I usually get a sushi tray..the food itself is cheap but combine it with a coupon and it's an awesome deal. If you like sushi and are a quantity over quality person Kitaro's is perfect for you.
author: Dan T.

description:
Surely there are other Japanese restaurants around my neighborhood that I could go to, but every time I crave for sushi, the first thing I think of is...Kitaro. The question is why?

With many different kinds of sushi (nigiri, makimono, special rolls) for under $3, under $7 lunch and under $10 dinner bento-boxes, there's no going wrong. The food is great, but parking can be tough around the area. Picking up food is a hassle if you order to-go, they give you an order number but never call the number and I've stood outside the door for half and hour waiting for my food that has been sitting by the cashier. If you don't dine-in, call your orders in for pick-up.

I especially do not like how all the tables are so close together, so close that I can feel the person next to me breathing :-)!  I do not mean to eavesdrop, but I can't help but listen to some of the conversations at the nearby tables.

An example of a conversation (my favorite):
A couple in their 20's to the right of us are enjoying their meal talking casually about their days and what they are going to do over the summer break. Boring, I know until...
Woman says: "So, my roommate keeps asking me when I'll move in with you."
Man sits quietly in shock. 
For 5-minutes, I too waited for his respond, but the couple sat silently, dead silent. The guy took his chopsticks and shoved a nigiri albacore into his mouth. Talking resumed between the two of them, but neither of them brought up the "moving in" comment. Ha-ha-ha.... so awkward, the guy just sat there pretending not to have heard her.

Need a coupon? Print it out from this web address:
http://kitarosushi.com/kitaro/coupon.html
author: Celeste M.

description:
Who can go wrong with cheap ass sushi rolls? I can't! Although I haven't been there recently because I wanna try out real sushi else where. I like to order their Pink Dragon, Dragon, Rainbow, Tekka, and their combination bentos. I like eating here when I'm broke and craving Japanese food.

Service is not always good. Sometimes I get too much attitude and that's a big no, no on my books!
author: Juliane N.

description:
Great prices and great vegetarian options!  The Irish roll is fantastic!!

Very quick service as well!
author: Sireenah M.

description:
I've ventured to this part of town a handful of times each year but am glad to report some fine eats here, including Ton Kiang, Tommy's Mexican Restaurant & here, Kitaro.

The Tiger Roll & tekka maki were fresh, tasty & reasonably priced and the steaming toasty gemaicha tea warded off the looming low fog outside.  For the daring, several spicy sushi plates may have smoke rising from your thinking cap.

Even though it was a long ride home, I'm certain I'll be back.  Thanks for the introduction to Geary Street dining!
author: Jen L.

description:
I would never have combined the words "sushi" and "cheap" before eating at Kitaro.
They have wonderful lunch specials and their five piece sushi sets start at 2.99 and cap at 4.99.
Really, two drinks and a full belly for an Andrew Jackson.
Nix the alcohol, go with a Coke and make it a sawbuck.
All that and the Sushi is competently prepared, tasty if a little bit sticky with the rice.
AND the service is outstanding, no rushing yet they are very good at getting to you as you finish to make sure that you've had enough.
I've eaten here seven times over the years, and nothing makes me want to move back out to the Richmond District more.
I hope it never closes.
Oh, the only caveat is that on the weekends and evenings, it can get VERY busy.
author: Theo R.

description:
Definitely not a stellar Japanese restaurant, but the prices are very fair. While the rolls aren't authentic and the fish not supremely fresh, they're fun and decent enough for a casual night out with friends who just want quick rolls to satiate their cravings.  Also, parking isn't easy here.
P.S.  If you shop at Safeway, seek the back of the receipt for coupons to this place: discounts off the total bill when you dine-in or for their party platters.
author: Valerie F.

description:
The Mexican roll man...that's the smell of my CHILDHOOD right there. My family has been going here ever since it was a hole in the wall on 23rd. Sure, it's not the most authentic of places (not that I would know anyway) but there are about 2908236527652764 other sushi places in San Francisco (three on the same block) and they all do their shit differently. If you're eating at Kitaro get either the sushi rolls or a bento box. The latter are really huge and delicious for what you pay for. My mother's a big fan of the teriyaki steak. So I would probably never eat the sashimi there, so one of the masks on the wall has a very phallic looking nose, so the service sucks and you have to ask for tea now. So they're the Naan 'n Curry of the japanese food world. I fucking love Naan 'N Curry and it hits the spot time and again. 

(ps they started serving frozen yogurt and it was awwwwesooome)
author: Nadia P.

description:
Their katsu was extremely dry, but it came at a good price I guess-cheap (yay!). 

Godzilla roll is the way to go though. If anything, go here for that.
author: Pearl V.

description:
My god man, the sushi here is inexpensive. I'm talking, so inexpensive that you consistently order so much stuff that it becomes expensive. 

Average special roll price is between $2 - $5 and very tasty. They make the sushi super quick, last time I went I don't think it took more than 5 minutes from the time I ordered to the time I was dipping my rolls in the most perfect soy-sauce to wasabi combination you've ever had. 

The restaurant itself is decent; I feel like the tables are too close together though, but I can deal. 

This restaurant has shown me that I can actually afford to eat good sushi multiple times a week. And for that they have my eternal love.
author: Justin B.

description:
I remember coming here whenever I was in the area as a kid. It's a Chinese run Japanese restaurant, but the workers don't admit it. That's kind of weird because most of the places on Geary are Chinese run. There's nothing embarrassing about that. Anyways, the restaurant is clean, and the bathrooms are presentable. No complaints about that. The restaurant is usually busy during busy hours, so either get to go or expect a wait. I never got to go, so I don't really know anything about that.

As for the food, when I came here as a kid, the portions used to be huge. Nowadays when I come, the portions are smaller, and the dinner portions are around the same as the lunch portions in the past. That's bit depressing. I came here lately. The other food wasn't super amazing, but the price isn't super high either. You get what you pay for, so don't expect some amazing stuff.

As for places on Geary, I think it's the best place for quantity in terms of Japanese food.
author: Glen H.

description: I  like this place. I used to live around the corner and it was a good place to get some cheap sushi. The food itself was not crappy either... but then again not as good as some other places in the city. HOWEVER, the GARLIC ALBACORE is the best here... fins down.
author: Serina H.

description: I've had so much better sushi for the same price as this.  Thoroughly underwhelmed even though I wasn't expecting much.
author: Paul C.

description:
Decent sushi at great prices.

Firecracker roll pretty much kicks butt... and I had the tempura/salmon sashimi combo last night, which was also pretty good. Boyfriend had a california roll and a tempura roll, with a cup of miso on the side... Added bonus (in his eyes) that the Cali roll didn't include cucumber (he's allergic), added bonus in my eyes for the fact that a) he'll eat here without complaining, and b) I got to watch him drink a girly, fruity blue cocktail served in a martini glass, complete with a pink paper umbrella.
author: Elle Q.

description: The ultimate evolution of a cheap sushi joint. Good cooked food and appetizers, excellent rolls at preposterously low prices.
author: Henry P.

description: Thank God I live close to this place.Pros:  Low prices and good services. Cons: PARKING -can be a nightmare and they could honestly add more sushi specialty rolls. Either way, I like Kitaro more than the other two sushi spots on the block.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
Solid sushi experience. Sashimi box hit the spot when happy hour went too long last week and I needed nutrition quickly. The sake selection is small and the unfiltered cold sake I had was too sweet. 

I go here once every two years whether I need to or not and always come away happy and well-nourished.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
We went out there last night with a group and it was okay.... As everyone else has said it is "cheap".  There were six of us and one person didn't have to pay for dinner.... so between all of us and drinks and a ton of food it came to $23 per person including tip.

The food wasn't horrible by any means... and it wasn't great either.. It just was.  The service was friendly and fast and they pretty much left us alone while we ate and chatted.  

It isn't a place that I would make a special trip to, but if someone suggested it again I wouldn't say "no way"......
author: Robin G.

description:
So, I am almost as picky about my sushi joints as I am about my taquerias......almost. 
Kitaro....I hadn't been back in almost 7 years since the first time I visited this place, frankly, because it wasn't that good 7 years ago. 
I decided, mainly because I was outnumbered 6 to 1, to give it another go. 
It still isn't that good. Didn't really see anything new or unique on the menu. I also have to question a sushi place that does all of the assembly in the back kitchen. There is something inherently wrong with this.
I have never gotten sick eating here, the food is edible, but not much more. 
The reason it scores as high as it does is the price. This place is cheap as far as sushi places go.....alas, you get what you pay for.
author: Drue C.

description:
Cheap & bad sushi

If you want to spend $10 for dinner and feel like vomiting after, give it a try!
author: stephanie ..

description:
Seeing all these low reviews is surprising because I have been there about 5 times and I have never been disappointed. The food is great the service is fast and the prices are cheap. I love coming here when in SF to get my sushi on. Food wise it compares with higher end places but with super reasonable prices. 

Try Rock And Roll and the firecracker with extra orange sauce.
author: Mike T.

description:
Cheap but food is pretty nasty.  The staff are very very rude.  The price is very cheap but it doesn't mean "you get what you paid for," I've been to much MUCH better japanese places that's around the same price. 

And I hate how they answer the phone. They just say "Hello?!?!" in a rude I'm-busy-what-do-you-want kinda way. I always have to ask if it's kitaro because I always think I have the wrong number.
author: Vivian M.

description:
i love kitaro! the quality of their sushi isn't top notch, but this place is good! and cheap too!

i have a love for teriyaki sauce, so the kitaro roll is a must have. it's chicken teriyaki and avocado in a roll. 

here's the list of rolls i always get :)
fire cracker - salmon and albacore sushi tempura with spicy mayo and teriyaki sauce
spicy chicken (ask for extra spicy mayo on the side) - fried chicken, green leaf lettuce with spicy mayo
spider - soft shell crab
surfer - albacore poke topped with seaweed salad

and their entrees are HUGE, definitely a good place to get japanese food for the money conscious!
author: Bianca W.

description:
A former friend introduced me to this place a few years back.

He felt it was one of those rare places that met the special three criteria (not sure where he got the test from but it was interesting):

1. Fast service
2. Good food; and
3. Cheap

I agree that all three points are true if you understand they are not using high quality food components.

That said, most people who have eaten here and who are not food connoisseurs do tend to like this place very much.

Parking can be a challenge and the street is metered.  It's good to come here at night when you no longer have to worry about meter maids.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Chicken teriyaki. California rolls. Miso soup. Typical American style Japanese restaurant. And like your typical American style Japanese restaurant, the food is just ok. Nothing to praise. 

The prices are cheap,a nice variety of rolls, and the portions are a good size for what you pay for.  Favorite roll would Godzilla. The sushi platters are a decent price too if you don't want to eat in.
author: Jonathan A.

description: Order the sushi party platters. $25 bucks for about 30 pieces [raw, cooked, or mix] Coupons are in the back of the receipts of the near by grocery stores like safeway or they mail em if you live in the outer richmond area[also can find em on websites like sfadvertiser.com] . Since I stay close I do my self a favor and just order take out because it is much more cheaper because they don't even offer those sushi platters in the restaurant. I tried a lot of their other items and nothing really stood out and was pretty comparable to other competitors. So, the point of my review is to order the party platters. Sushi rolls are good and cheap.
author: Jeff C.

description: I used to eat here often back when the food was better.  During my last two visits here I ordered the California roll, which I once enjoyed until the restaurant became lazy or cheap and no longer shredded the imitation crab with their usual sauce/mayo.  No more California rolls for me =(
author: Jen P.

description:
The food here is pretty good for the price.  The prices are really cheap and the portions are pretty big. The chicken selections are great, but beef dishes taste like rubber.  Other than that, I will keep going to this place.  Get in, eat your food, and get out.  

The service is almost non-existent, but for the price you pay you learn to overlook this.
author: Louis V.

description:
Being that I've come here several times, and not really remembering anything about this place, other than it's sashimi is old, and it smells like chlorine, I don't really understand why this place is so raved about.  Okay, it is affordable I'll give you that, and the cooked rolls are ok, but when your sashimi is tough and TASTES old, that's a bad sign...i don't really think ANY quality sashimi should taste old....  I would come in here and eat again, but only if my friends wanted to and i'd probably get the cooked stuff.  There are so many other good restaurants on Geary that I'd rather visit Aziza or even the chinese place next door has good food!  Not to mention NO wait.  

Some people like Kitaro and some don't , and I think I'm in the category of someone who doesn't, unfortunately.....but win some, lose some....
author: Linda C.

description:
Cheap and good Japanese food, hard to find =P
I took my mom here, she like it too. I like to go usually with some friends. This is one of those places where I am not shy about ordering a ton of food since the price is very reasonable.
The food isn't mind blowing awesome, but it's decent, and at a really good price.
The sake is cheap too!
author: Jenny W.

description:
I ordered once from Kitaro a few years ago and was not impressed.  There was chicken in one of my rolls ~_^  

I'll pass on the faux sushi.
author: Helen B.

description:
yes....could i have the dinner combo please! A must have in the list of favs...WHY? SUSHI, cheap, fast service, and it seems fresh. Granted you will find a better sushi resturant that serves better sushi, but for the price that you pay, this place will satisfy your sushi desires~!

The waiters/waitresses are also pretty cool. Although there is one elderly woman who seems to be mad at the world...hmmmm. But aside from her, I think they always have an inviting service.

Aside from that, I've been to this restaurant  oober amount of times and have always been happy and most importantly never been sick!
author: Janine P.

description:
While I really wanted to go to Minami Restaurant at 21st and Clement, there were not open until 5pm :( So my tubby girlfriend and I drove around to find another place to satisfy our bento box craving. 
And we stumbled into Kitaro and what a mistake that was! I mean the menu itself should have been an indication of the quality but we were blinded by hunger. 

-My girlfriend got an ordinary lunch bento box, which wasn't terrible. California roll was decent, eel roll was eh, and the tempura roll was eh too. But for $8, it was filling and cheap.
-I got some kind of spicy tuna roll and another fried spicy yellowtail roll. Both of them were terrible. The tuna was mushy and ground up into a mush of nastiness. Also, the tuna roll was cut into these awkward diagonal shapes, supposedly to exaggerate the meager amounts of tuna in the sushi. And then the fried roll was soggy and absolutely drenched in sauce, and served in a bowl. Did I order a sushi roll or a bowl of soup?
-One more thing about the sushi. The tuna and yellowtail rolls were $5 and $4 respectively, which in my mind should have triggered an alarm of suspicion. Even at those prices, its not worth it. 
-I also ordered a tonkatsu-don. Pork fried cutlet with egg and rice. I was good but nothing special. And honestly, its pretty easy to make a decent tonkatsu. Only $6, so I guess it was worth it.

As they say, hunger is the best spice. Without it, this meal would have been disgusting and unsatisfying. I think you should avoid the sushi at Kitaro. Stick with donburi bento boxes at lunch time. The saving grace of this restaurant is the average lunch dishes at above average prices.
author: Aron L.

description:
I must say... I was quite the skeptic of low cost sashimi.. and I still am for the most part. this place is wonderful if you're that short on cash.. but you must ask yourself how much risk you are willing to take with lower-grade fish and sake?

it's probably better to spent a couple more bucks and go easy on your liver
author: Martin B.

description:
Kitaro is good for a quick sushi fix (I'm talking rolls)  that won't break the bank. The Philly Roll is actually better than most (good cream cheese to salmon ratio) and the Spider roll (one of things I judge all sushi places by) also decent, granted it's just fried soft shell crab, it's crunchy and not oily. 

The staff has always been cool, even when it gets busy and it's great for take out. Not the best sushi place in the neighborhood, but definitely the best value-you could do alot worse or pay alot more (Blue Fin).
author: Raf Z.

description:
3 stars for what it is. 
A basic, no frills, college feed bag, sushi place. In the sunset you have Irving St. Ebisu. In the Richmond dist. You have Kitaro. Place is busy any time of the day. Its a neighborhood tradition.  One of three on sushi row. Fish is so so. You get what you pay for. Take the date and save a couple bucks, what!
author: William H.

description:
I like to go here for cheap sushi but you'll take the risk of food poisioning.  I had this unfresh fish and I ended up in the bathroom that whole night paying for it. blah. 

I don't eat there anymore unless we buy the party trays for work potlucks or something... because most of the party trays are cooked!
author: Mary W.

description: I only had sushi when I came here. It was inexpensive and pretty okay quality. The servers don't really check up on you. I guess that's why they give a whole pot of tea instead of a little cup they have to keep refilling. (They charge $0.39 for tea). There wasn't anything too special about this place except that it was inexpensive.
author: Tiffany P.

description: This place is perfect for cheap, but really decent sushi. You can come with $20 and leave happy and with change. I have never been dissapointed with their food.
author: Chris B.

description:
Wow. I just realized that Sahar S. came here without me. Then I realized that I didn't know her then. Or did I? I suck at math.

My roommate and i had in total six rolls for 32 dollars. tip included. Yes, and it was delicious. Not melt in  your mouth delicious, but solid good food delicious. 32 dollars. six rolls. That's like what, less than 6 bucks a roll? 

Oh, we had trouble getting home though. Had to do with overstuffedness and inability to overcome it.
author: Jenny M.

description: very good service love their food. price is descent and has great amount . its kind of like a fast food japanese resturant . service is excellent
author: Paul Y.

description:
When I remembered that my typical sushi place, Ebisu, was closed on Sundays, my wife suggested we go to Kitaro.  We'd been there once before and had a good experience.

We had miso soup, which didn't have any tofu, but was good and hot.  We then had Firecrakers, Dynamite Roll, Spicy Tuna, and Futo Maki.

The Firecrakers were great, and the dynamite roll was also very good - very similar to the firecrackers.  Always nice to have fried food. Yummy.    We noticed that the Spicy Tuna and Futo Maki were only cut into 5 pieces, not the 6 that I'm accustomed to.  5 pieces are harder to share than 6.  The Futo Maki was good.  The Spicy Tuna was not my favorite.

Overall, there was less selection and smaller portions than our usual Ebisu.  The price tag was much lower too - which was nice.  

Overall, good quality cheap sushi.
author: Bill V.

description:
It's OK. Kitaro is probably the cheapest sushi restaurant I've ever been to. Most specialty rolls that can be anywhere from $10-$16 at any other sushi restaurant were no more than $7. 

If you're in a pinch for money this place is worth it, for sure. I would highly recommend the dynamite roll; it was pretty awesome. It's spicy tuna, lightly fried with spicy sauce. It was delicious and only like $5. 

We were seated right away and the service was really fast although not incredibly friendly. The ambiance was nice as well; very open, with colorful paper lamps (I know there's an actual word for these but have no clue what it is) that seem to add just the perfect amount of cultural decor. 

It didn't disappoint but I have had better. It's a good alternative if you're unemployed (Ali...just kidding I love you!), cheap or in a hurry.
author: Kristin R.

description:
Coming from the Bay Area, land of Japanese immigrants and thus many many sushi bars/restaurants, it's natural that I can spot bad sushi when I see/taste it. 

That said, Kitaro isn't the best place I have ever been to but if I'm craving sushi and really want to lighten the blow on my bank account, Kitaro is the place to go.

I also like that they accomodate vegetarians better as well. If I'm not feeling like fish, I don't have to strictly stick to the kappa roll. 

Great place.
author: Courtney S.

description:
Not the best sushi but not bad either. Their special rolls range from $2.99-$7. The udon isn't the best here but it's still good. I usually come here for lunch since dinner is an additional $2-3 on top of the items you order for bento boxes. I love their oshinko rolls and tempura rolls. That's a must have when i come here. The teriyaki salmon isn't bad either. 

The only reason why this place isn't a 5 star is because they drown their salad in dressing and their service isn't that great. The waiters never give us time to look over the menu. They seat us and then 30 seconds later they come and ask if we're ready. Like wth come on now, let our butts settle down on the chair first.
author: Tracy A.

description:
This place gets one star just because I thought the decor was pretty, and the staff were friendly, and it was actually OPEN in the middle of the afternoon, which...apparently is exceptional because every other place I checked in the immediate vicinity was closed until 5.

I got three rolls for under $10. I shouldn't have any room to complain--except I've gotten sushi JUST as cheap at other places, and it was actually GOOD there. Or at least decent.

I got a pumpkin roll, a salmon roll, and a rock'n'roll. The pumpkin was actually pretty good--a little dry, but tasty. The salmon roll was meh. The fish wasn't that fresh. The thing that was insulting was the rock'n'roll. It was loosely rolled, and although it appeared big, it had a thick layer of rice, even MORE rice on the inside, a LOT of underripe avacado, and like...one small piece of low-quality unagi. I couldn't even taste the fish. AND the thing was rolled so loosely that the avacado slices kept falling out. It was ridiculous.

If I'd paid any real money for it I would've been PISSED. As it was I was just like, "Dude, this place blows, let's get outta here."

And so we did.
author: Lynae Z.

description:
I gave it 3 stars cuz they have great prices. The food is decent. You get what you pay for. So if you're only paying $5 for a roll, don't expect to get the grand pooba of seafood. I didn't get sick and it was decent.

i'm wondering why they don't have a line like they used to at the door. I had to wait at least 20-30 minutes for a table a few years ago. These past 2 times, I walked in and picked one of the many open tables.  

Oh well, I'll still go back.
author: Ames K.

description:
The bargain basement Sushi Joint.  In my circle, I always hear people bad mouthing this place but I think it's decent.  Better than your Costco Sushi for sure.  They always have those Sushi Party Trays advertised in the back of your grocery receipts.  For about $20-$25, you get a decent amount.  

Haven't actually ate at the restaurant in many years but once in a long while, we'll still order a party tray when we got a party.  

Sometimes I get scared eating at some nice sushi places cause it can get REALLY expensive to get full but this is like the Anti-Expensive sushi place......
author: Mark W.

description:
I think i've had the worst donburi in my life here. I ordered a vegetable donburi and it turned out to be disappointing in taste and choice of veggies used in the dish.

I wouldn't mind coming back to Kitaro in the future for a cheap eat, but I'd be sure to order something different.
author: Bets Y.

description:
This is the best sushi I've had so far.  
I'll explain...As I've written before, I'm not a big-time sushi guy.  So I've had it a few times, and always kinda liked it but never thought enough to write home about it.  Maybe I just wasn't ordering the right dishes.  But this time I did and I thought this is something I'll have to have again sometime.

I really liked the spider rolls and dynamite rolls.  I hear the Godzilla rolls are also good stuff.  The salmon makimono sushi was pretty good, as were the Kamikaze rolls.  I also liked the pumpkin makimono.  
Okay, I pretty much like pumpkin anything.  

I realize there are fancier sushi places, and I may just like those more whenever I get around to 'em, but this one really hit the spot.
author: Charles R.

description:
I've been here twice.  Haven't been totally happy but its not a total loss.  The only thing I really like here are the firecracker rolls for the price and amount of food.  The sushi here is just disappointing and the rolls may be cheaper, but they lack a good amount of raw fish in it.  I had the Alaska Roll which had barely any salmon in it.  The rice is supposed to go around the outside of the roll, but there was some stuffed inside of it as well - this makes the roll look artificially bigger when all it is is a bunch of rice.  Same goes for a roll that had Hamachi in it, and the amount of fish was so little that I couldn't taste the difference between the two.

For the price, the bento boxes looked quite small and my dad had the mackerel that was quite a bit dry.  My sister had the daily special that consisted of japanese curry udon, which had a good portion of chicken in it  Not very tasty though, we just dug out the noodles and chicken and ate that.

Not impressed at all considering the options in the bay area  I only came here to eat because it was close to where I live.  There are usually MANY coupons out in the circular and it may be worth it to use them to eat at this place if all you're looking for is a mediocre meal.

Firecrackers = $3
Rolls = $6
Curry udon with chicken katsu = $7
author: Patrick C.

description:
FOOD:   Not the finest sushi, but you definitely get more than your money's worth here.   Great quality food at an exceptional price.  I think that's what Kitaro aims for and it accomplishes just that.  I mean if you're looking for high quality stuff than you obviously should go somewhere more spendy. 

AMBIANCE:  Casual setting, nothing too original.

SERVICE:  Fast serivce, though not very personal.

OVERALL:  Good Bargain.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I used to come here a lot when I lived down the street, and since we were going to go to Blarney Stone down the block, I decided to give Kitaro another try for old time's sake.  Years ago, when I used to come here, I was not very picky about my sushi's freshness or flavor.  I just wanted CHEAP!  And I forgot how cheap Kitaro is... and there's a reason why.

I was hesitant to order any sashimi or nigiri here since the prices were too cheap to be true.. also after glancing over to the sad, limp looking nigiri pieces on the table next to us, I decided to just get an order of tempura, which was standard.  My brother ordered an array of rolls that were all under $4 each.. they were all piled with some sort of sauce to mask the flavor of the obviously unfresh fish.  

Overall, a cheap go-to if you are desperate and can't afford better sushi...
The rolls are decent, but stay away from the nigiri/sashimi.
author: Jeannette P.

description: Hey, this little Japanese restaurant has been my go to place for years.  They literally have the best Chicken Teriyaki in the City.  They used to be 6 dollars after tax, now it has gotten a little more expensive but the value is still there.  You can't find a more fulfilling and delicious plate of chicken for less anywhere else.  Go to Kitaro, they are awesome.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Four stars for "value for money."

Kitaro is basic sushi with a few ok additions.  Veg tempura is pretty good.  But the key to appreciating the prices here is getting a hold of their Val Pak coupons.

I know - how cheesy.  I'm admitting I use coupons.  But seriously - their large sushi platters are a great value.  You have to pick up but, not too horrible.

We order 15 minutes in advance, jet in with coupon, jet out - and spend a couple hours catching up on Tivo - with some respectable store-bought chardonnay.

You staying in tonight?  Check your coupons - and go for the sushi platters.  Please, no grumbles over it's not being "gourmet" sushi.  It's easily a "B" so stop yer whinin'.  Sometimes, cheap is good!
author: Juliana C.

description:
they don't "need" another review, but since we went there last night, here's a recent one . . . .

Sunday at 6:30, found parking after about 5 minutes of circling the blocks.

Waited for a table for 2 for about 10 minutes after signing up which was a little surprising since it was only 6:30, but not too long of a wait to complain at all.  Sunday night = lots of families eating at 6:00.

Firecrackers were our favorite.

We noticed that the rolls, which are inexpensive,  were not rolled all that well, i.e., they fall apart if they are not deep-fried, and most rolls consist of five-pieces instead of the traditional six pieces.

Average flavor, but not send-it-back-never-come-here-again bad.

Service was fast, and while it's not my first choice for sushi, it worked for a Sunday night sushi craving in this part of the city (Ebisu on 9th is closed on Sundays so this is why we ended up here).
author: TC C.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat..ever.Hands down.Awesome. 

I've been coming to Kitaro for the past couple years,and not once have I ever been disappointed with anything.Service is always prompt,even when they're packed to the gills.The staff all work as a team and I'm always taken care of. 

Weather I'm in a group of 13 people,out with the fam,or on a date..the prices have never even come close to breaking the bank.I also love that no matter who I bring here,theres something for everyone,even the sushi naysayers (though you can bet if I'm on a date..if hes a naysayer its pretty much a deal breaker ;D ) 

I've tried every roll on the menu,and while I have my favorites,I can safely assert that everything is delicious.The fish is always fresh,and a lot of the rolls are creative with amazing flavors that I haven't found anywhere else. 

I haven't strayed too far from the sushi because I love it so,but I'll give special notes to the grilled squid,fried tofu,and soft shell crab.All of which are staples when I go out with my family.Between the 4 of us,we can eat like Kings (or piggies..really) and not spend over 65 bucks...including beer and sake. 

I even enjoy the booth seating.It gives it a family comfort,but you aren't ever distracted from the people you came with.The ambiance is nothing but warm and inviting...especially on a frigid city night. 

If you haven't been here,you're certainly missing out.
author: Jessica D.

description:
This is not a place for real sushi. This is not a place for the greatest fish.

What I'm saying is ... yes, I could go to Okina Sushi instead every time I wanted japanese ... but that's like saying I'd rather go to Morton's every time I wanted beef ... sometimes you just want some Burger King.

Here's why I like it despite the fact it's faux sushi:

1) It's dirt cheap (be sure to check your Albertson's and Safeway receipts for the 15% off coupon)

2) Sometimes you just want a roll that's covered in sauce and fried ... 

3) Sake bombing!

I would probably NEVER get the nigiri or sashimi ... that'd be like buying a steak at Lucky Penny (and yes I've done that).
author: Alex C.

description:
WHY DO PEOPLE EAT HERE ??!!

overrated like a mother f*er
author: Anthony N.

description:
This is like crack for cocaine addicts....

You just need somethin to take the edge off before you can afford the good stuff.
author: Stacy L.

description:
i love this place.

my friends and i come here for their really cheap sushi. i'm giving them 4 because of the prices and their sushi are pretty decent.

they have rolls for $2.99 and above. never seen any restaurant with that price before. we come here for dinner and my meals are with $10-12, including tip and tax. of course, i usually get the basic rolls. if you want their special rolls, price ranges usually from $5-8, which I say are still pretty good.
author: Viola C.

description:
This is the best place to get take out. They have really cheap sushi and it's always really nicely presented. I usually get the spicy salmon rolls with the rice on the outside, and they nail it. They've got a great vegetarian list for nigiri, and you can literally alter any order to your liking. 

The people aren't the friendliest, but they're quick to serve. They get super busy on the weekends, so you have to get there at a reasonable time. Parking usually sucks in that neighborhood too.
author: Mei F.

description:
I'm not really a fan of sushi, but even I enjoyed it here. ..though maybe it's because I didn't veer away from the traditional California rolls and spicy tuna rolls. The food is decent, but the prices are great (read: super affordable).  The rolls tasted good, though even I could tell that it wasn't the most fresh ingredients.  

One surprising treat, though, was the guava juice! Most places don't serve guava juice, so I was tempted to try it when I saw it on the menu...and it was definitely worth it!  Just the right amount of sweetness...mmMmmmMM.

A friend of mine ordered the mango sushi and the Philly-style sushi, both of which he enjoyed.  The quantities are large, and the total of both of  our meals was under $30!  I've recommended it to a couple of friends who were in the neighborhood at the time (Outer Richmond) and according to them, it was delicious...so maybe you have to be more adventurous to try to less conventional rolls, in order to really appreciate this place.
author: Anjali M.

description:
My girlfriend and I were just looking for a place to eat in the Outer Richmond, and there was a pretty decent-sized crowd for a Wednesday night, the price was right, so we decided to go in.

Good, cheap food - nothing to write home about, but a solid choice for a quick and cheap meal.  Edamame and tempura udon were exactly what I expected.  Nice decor, the place doesn't feel really cheap... that's all I've got to say about that.
author: Chris R.

description:
FOOD: FOUR STARS (* * * *)
Is it the highest-quality sushi in the city?  Probably not, but you're paying $2.50 for that Salmon Makimono so shut your mouth.  I have consistently enjoyed my meals here both dining in and taking out--a total of probably 20 times over the past two years.  They have the basic sushi fare of Rock N' Rolls (eel with avocado) and California Rolls, and also some other creations I enjoy, such as the Tiger Roll (tempura shrimp wrapped in seaweed, rice and alternating layers of avocado and eel).  Bottom line: you're not going to be blown away by creative culinary visions or artful food presentations, but you are definitely going to enjoy your food for what it is.

ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS (* * *)
The environment is basic--no question--but at these prices, it's not much of a surprise.  Stark walls are interspersed with dusty old masks from what appears to be an elementary school project.  There is a "second floor" around 5 feet tall (viewable from the first floor) that holds a smattering of what seems like useless flotsam, contributing nothing to the decor.  The service is quick and to the point (the first visit to the table is usually accompanied with "you know what you want?").

VALUE: FIVE STARS (* * * * *)
In terms of sushi, I have never seen such a good value.  Basic no-frills rolls start at $2.  More complicated fare involving several ingredients (avocado, green onions, etc) are slightly more, usually in the $3-5 range.  The most expensive rolls are around $8, and these include a lot of fish in them.  The menu offers many other items (seaweed salad for $4 and individual nigiri or sashimi) as well.  Make sure to bring a 15% off coupon which can be found on the back of Cala and Lucky receipts, among other places.

Average of
FOOD: FOUR STARS
ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS
VALUE: FIVE STARS
================
AVERAGED GRAND TOTAL: FOUR STARS

Estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$9-12

Would I recommend it to others?
Yes.

Would I return?
Yes, time and again.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Madness I tell ya .... madness! When Asians find a good food place that is a bargain, it's like piranhas feeding!

My friend and I went to Kitaro around 7pm on a Sat. Got there and was able to get a table but the madness has already descended. 

Service was quick and precise if not overly friendly. So was the food. The best part was the Firecracker Sushi dish. It was lightly deep fried with a sauce that literally "cracked" in your mouth. The Spider Roll unfortunately wasn't as crunchy. The Surfer roll was basically a Gozilla not fried. We also shared a Bento box of Teriyaki salmon and vegetable tempura. They were both good. I was surprised that my Amaebi although fresh didn't come with the deep fried heads like most places. Since it was getting more crowded and the wait staff was zipping by at 100mph, I didn't have the courage to ask. It was nice to share a meal with a friend. We left a little after 7:30pm with bodies piled 5 deep at the door. It didn't help the weather outside felt like winter. It did keep the place hopping and warm.

The best part of Kitaro is the prices. The Firecracker dish was only $2.99!! That type of pricing is rare in the world of sushi and not to mention in San Francisco.

My suggestion is to go on a weekday at down time. Hopefully the service will be better and you can actually relax and enjoy the meal.
author: Margaret M.

description: You'll understand why the place is full of college kids once you get your food. The prices are very good for japanese food, but there's a reason for that. The food is not horrible, but I wouldn't say it's 3 star worthy either. The sashimi is squishy and you can tell that it's been frozen for a while. The sushi rolls are mostly rice. Service is good, the restaurant is clean, and the wait is usually not too bad, so if you're looking for cheap sushi, this is the place for you. If you're looking for quality, look elsewhere.
author: Tyler C.

description:
I met a couple of good friends here for dinner last night and all I have to say is there is a reason why it's so cheap. Bleh. It was alright, but I've had better California and spicy tuna rolls at Safeway -- and for me to say that is B-A-D. Now, the bento boxes are a steal, I will give them that. I thought the katsu was awful to be honest, the only saving grace was the tempura - but come on, there aren't a lot of places that can screw up tempura veggies and shrimp. It was kind of icky too. The bathroom was gnarly. Thankfully I did not have to visit the porcelain god last night unnecessarily, but I'll be honest, I was worried about it.

Needless to say, next time we meet, it won't be at this place.
author: Susan B.

description:
There are certain japanese chain restauraunts that you know are ran by a chinese management, Kitaro is one of them. The food is decently affordable but authenticity & freshness gets the two stars. I had a unagi roll/chicken karaage combo lunch meal for 6.95 and a miso soup (+$1). 

they use the fake wasabi paste that tastes bland and doesn't give you that crack fix up your nose! 

 bottom line: quick & cheap sushi fix.
author: Fat C.

description:
